title: Are omniscience and free will compatible? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely. You have free will. For our purposes here, let’s assume I am omniscient. I know what you are going to do tomorrow, the next day, and the next, and so on. You may not know what you will be doing two days from now, but I know you are going to choose to answer a call you receive from a strange number. I know you are going to be pleased that it turns out to be an old friend. And I know that when you make arrangements to meet for lunch, you are going to choose this restaurant over that restaurant. You still have free will. My knowing it does nothing to affect your decision. Let’s suppose that you chose not to answer that call. I would have simply known that instead. Now, some believe that if it is God’s omniscience we’re talking about that can throw a wrinkle into the whole business, but I disagree. Theologians and philosophers have been debating this for thousands of years. God cannot know anything that is not true. So if God knows that a certain thing is going to happen, then it cannot happen any other way. So in one sense, it is predestined by God to occur in exactly that way. Once He knows it, it cannot be otherwise. However, we can also be sure that free will exists. I believe we would all agree that love exists, and free will is absolutely necessary for love to exist. God’s desire is that we love Him as He loves us. That has to be a free choice. As paradoxical as it sounds, no one can come to truly love God without the absolute freedom to reject Him. I talk about that briefly here. So how do we reconcile the two? Easy. I am in the camp of people that believe it makes no difference that God knows what you will do. He simply knows it will occur this way or that. You cannot change your mind and surprise God. He already knew you’d change your mind. Remember, it is foreknowledge; He knows it ahead of time. His knowing doesn’t determine what you are going to do. He only knows that you are going to do this thing or that thing. I may know my son is going to choose this dessert over that dessert. But do I really know it? No, I don’t. I know my son as in I am familiar with him, his tastes, his preferences, and his habits. But do I really know which he is going to choose, or do I just have a statistically good chance that I am going to be right? It is the latter. I actually could be wrong. That is not the sense in which God knows some future event. He knows with the certainty of Someone who has actually already witnessed the event take place because that is exactly what has happened. God knows everything you and I are going to do. From His perspective we have already done them. There is zero chance that anything will occur differently than He has already seen it take place. But God’s knowing that I will choose door #3 over door #1 or door #2 doesn’t make me choose door #3; He just knows that’s what I am going to freely choose to do because He has already seen me do it before I even did it.

Are omniscience and free will compatible? Depending on how you define omniscience… knowing all even things that will happen… no. There is no free will. There may be the illusion of free will.. But if an entity knows what you are going to do, before you do it… there is no option of changing your mind the end is already determined. Re watch a movie… the characters in the movie will do certain things, they cannot change their mind - but within the movie - they have ‘free will’ but to the outside observer… they don’t. they are on rails. Each time you watch the movie, everything is the same.

Are omniscience and free will compatible? No. If there’s an all knowing god who knows what we will do in the future it’s impossible we can do anything other than what God foresees. But it’s even worse than that: if God made everything (did he?) everything is as the creator decreed including your will so how can it possibly be free considering God made it as it is? The only way we can have free will is if there is no god.

Exhaustive definite foreknowledge is not logically possible with libertarian free will. Compatibilism/middle knowledge end up being deterministic in the end. It is a wrong assumption/conclusion to say that if free will exists, then God cannot be omniscient or cannot exist Himself. We can reject a wrong view of God's omniscience without denying omniscience or God's existence (hence Open Theism/dynamic vs static omniscience; future consisting of possibilities and known as such).

When you watch the video tape, re-run, or DVR of someone using their free will on Jeopardy for the 2nd, 3rd, or 4th time. You know what will happen. The original use of the free will was still free will. You’re also still seeing free will. It’s just recorded free will.  The analogy to Biff in Back to the Future II still holds as well. The sports stars were still making choices out of free will.

Omniscience means that the future is fixed. People who believe in libertarian free will claim that if the future is fixed there can be no freedom. Therefore, there can be no libertarian free will if omniscience is possible, but there can be compatibilist free will.
